The Open Story: Daedalus - PART 6

This is an epic story game set in an alternate universe to the official Mush story.

Part 1
Part 2
Part 3
Part 4
Part 5

But you don't have to read the previous parts of the story unless you really want to.
If you'd like to play, just let us know you're interested. We'll help you create a new character, and get you aboard the ship. We'll explain the current situation in the story through role-play with your character.

It wan't an RPG when it started, but that's basically what it evolved into. We have a Skills system, Research system, Combat mechanics, Inventory, etc. Our GM is EoNightcore


Combat and Skill Actions

We usually roll dice like this: d100+X% => d100

The first d100 is the action's chance of success. The +X is a modifier, determined by several factors described below. The second d100 is the actual attempt. If it's less than or equal to the modified chance, then the action succeeded.

If the modified chance is zero or less, that's critical failure - something bad will happen, like the character will hurt themselves. If it's 100 or more, then the action succeeds fantastically. In combat, that's 2x damage. (Although we don't really keep track of HP much, except for ships.) For non-combat actions, criticals can be interpreted however you want.

In other words
X>Y or X=Y, Success
X<Y, Fail

Skills

There are 5 Skill Levels:


  • Unskilled: -50%
  • Basic: -25%
  • Competent: -10%
  • Skilled: +10%
  • Expert: +25%Each character has 4 skill slots. The number of slots filled (regardless of skill level) determines an additional modifier:

  • Unique: Only one skill, +25% to all rolls for Unique Skill
  • Normal: Two or three skills, no modifier
  • Generalist: Four skills, -10% to all rollsIn the past, we used a Training Simulator to improve our characters' Skill Levels. It was a great idea, but it created a lot of useless clutter in the thread. (The sim was a spam factory!) So here's the new rule:

Characters advance in skill level by participating in the story. Skill Level promotions are given by the GM when they are needed or deserved due to excellent role-play.


Infection Detection - Research & Development

Detection R&D will "upgrade" through the following levels:

1. Brain biopsy [DONE]


  • Reliability: 95%
  • Results available in 1 day
  • Chance of brain damage - minimum 5%2. Eye biopsy [DONE]

  • Reliability: 75%
  • Results available in 1 hour
  • Chance of blindness in one eye - minimum 5%3. Biopsy Scanner (takes a skin sample) - Reliability: 50% [DONE]
    4. Proximity Detector (within same room) - Reliability: 60%
    5. Remote Ship Scanner (narrow beam, 10km range) - Reliability: 70%
    6. Planetary Scanner (entire planet from orbit) - Reliability: 80%

The first two levels of biopsy require a skill action for Surgery. Brain damage or partial blindness are caused by critical failure, or if the second roll is 96-100. Non-critical failure means the biopsy was not obtained, and must be performed again. The analysis must be performed by Jessica, and the reliability of the results are determined by the procedure (not a skill action).

The Biopsy Scanner and Proximity Detector are hand-held devices. The other two devices are installed on the ship. Any character can use the detection devices. This is not a skill action because the devices are automatic.

The actual detection is a simple d100 against Reliability, to be performed by a GM in private chat. When detection fails, the result is a coin toss. When it succeeds, the GM will reveal true Mush infection status.

Progress for each Detection level begins at 0%. Any character can participate in research to advance the progress. When it reaches 100%, that level is complete.

R&D requires time and concentration. A character who is working on R&D cannot be doing anything else at the same time.

Here is the template for R&D participation:
[character] works on Infection Detection for [d4] hours.
Progress increased by: x%

The "x%" contribution to R&D progress depends on the character's skills:

Summary
After the Daedalus traveled to Darkor, they traveled to the fringes of the system, before going back to Darkor.
On Darkor they tested the (captured by aliens earlier) crew members for Mushiness, getting a negative on one, and a positive for two others, one of them escaping into the outside world. Dawn went insane at this point, and the crew hired a new crew member to "fix" Dawn.
They took the two remaining crew members with them, and went back into space.
They proceeded to travel to another nebula, and then Charles went insane, and Dawn went all insane, again. Then some masked man stuck them into their own minds and threw them into a portal, along with anyone in the Cafeteria.

Fast forward 10 hours later
Some of the crew is now fighting some enemy in the Nebula, and others are still stuck in their own minds.

[8356287]

Sleeping face-down on the Bio Lab workbench, Jessica had a dream. She was inside a cage, in a wide-open stretch of bleak landscape under dark clouds that flashed with lightning. The psycho pilot was there, laughing his crazy laugh. Elephants were falling from the sky, trumpeting in terror.

Then a man in a mask appeared. He reached down to touch the cage, and it disappeared.

"I have something to show you, Jessica."

A swirling vortex of darkness opened up beside him and pulled her in. She tumbled down, down through the darkness, until it swallowed her into oblivion, and everything faded to white.

"Let me show you the past..."

... ... ...

A high-ranking military officer was sitting at his desk, reviewing reports. There was a knock at the door.

"Come in."

Charles entered the room, and Jessica stumbled backward as he walked right past her.

"He can't see you."

"You asked for me, Commander?"

"Sit down."

Charles took a seat in front of the desk.

"I'm giving you a special assignment. There is a civilian pilot working in freight delivery. You are to bring him in and train him as one of our own."

"Recruitment, Sir?"

"Not exactly. There is a warrant for his arrest. We're going to offer him amnesty in exchange for his service in the Air Force."

Charles hesitated. "...May I ask what his crime was?"

"Are you questioning my authority?"

"No, Sir. I will see to it."

"Yes, you will. Dismissed."

Charles left the room and Jessica turned to the man in the mask.

"I know it wasn't his fault. I don't blame Charles. He was just following orders. But... why the hell was he given those orders?!"

"Would you like to see what happened before that?"

Jessica started to answer, but the room faded to white.

... ... ...

The psychotic pilot was sitting on his couch, with a gun in one hand, and a beer in the other.

Jessica was afraid, but the man in the mask took her hand.

"You are safe here, Jessica. You're only here to watch."

The phone rang.

The pilot ignored it for two rings, then gulped down the rest of his beer and answered it.

"Hullo?... Who is this? ... Not interested."

He hung up the phone. Moments later it rang again. He threw his empty beer can across the room.

"WHAT!"

He listened for a long time without saying a word.

"*sigh* ...Alright. I'll be there."

He hung up and stumbled to the door as everything faded to white.

... ... ...

Jessica found herself standing beside a table in the back corner of a dimly-lit restaurant. The pilot was seated across from another man, who slid a large manilla envelope toward him. The pilot opened it and flipped through the pages. A photograph of herself was paper-clipped to one of them. After a while, he threw the stack down onto the table, rattling several empty beer bottles.

"Th' fuck is this bullshit?"

The other man cleared his throat and spoke in a raspy voice. "Do you know anything about trauma-based mind control?"

"Nope."

The man shrugged. "Doesn't matter. I'm offering you a job, and I promise I'll make it worthwhile. Will you do it?"

The pilot glanced at the papers and shook his head. "Pshhh, NO WAY. Tha's fuckin' crazy."

The man stood up. "Then you leave me no choice."

He pulled open his suit coat slightly to reveal a blaster holstered under his arm.

The pilot glared up at the man. "Go ahead... S'all I WANT. You gon' make it reeeal easy on me, huh?"

The man paused, then buttoned his coat and sat down again. "It doesn't have to be this way. I know what you really want. I know some... people - in high places. I could make some arrangements for you.... Put the past behind you. I'm offering you a new life - the life you've always dreamed of. But if you... decline, I assure you that your END will be quite prolonged and most undesirable."

The pilot hesitated, then picked up the papers again, reading them more closely. After a while, he tossed them down again and slumped forward, resting his forehead on his knuckles. The other man reached into his coat and pulled out a small vial of reddish liquid. He concealed it in his fist and reached across the table.

"Here. Take this."

The pilot stared at the man's hand for a few seconds, then took the vial. "What is it?"

"Something to make you... strong. Give you the courage to do what you must."

The pilot stuffed it into his pocket, and the room faded white.

... ... ...

Jessica was in the passenger seat of a dirty sedan. The pilot was in the driver's seat, staring out the window toward her own house, across the street.

He took a deep, ragged sigh and pulled out the vial. He swirled it around, watching the red liquid cling to the glass. Opening the cap, he threw his head back and gulped it down.

He choked and sputtered, gripping the steering wheel, coughing and gasping. As the coughing subsided, an inhuman growl raised in his throat and grew to a ROAR, and then broke into wild laughter. He swung open the door and began walking toward her house as everything faded to white.

... ... ...

Jessica was standing between a rusty car and a shiny black limosine with dark tinted windows. The man with the raspy voice was shouting at the pilot.

"...yet you failed to COMPLETE the assignment!"

The pilot threw his hands up in the air. "But she doesn't HAVE to die! She's harmless!!"

"She knows too MUCH. Take care of it - or I will take care of you."

The pilot reached up and grabbed fist-fulls of his own hair. Jessica could somehow hear the pilot's thoughts.

I can't.... I can't do it. There's gotta be another way. But... with those damn military bastards watching my house, I can't risk it! ...Poor girl, I never meant to leave her down there so long...

The raspy voice spoke again. "I'll make it easy for you. Go to your job. Today will be your last day working there, as I've already made arrangements for your new job. The destination of your cargo delivery is a warehouse I own. Inside you will find everything you need to finish it. DO NOT FAIL."

He handed the pilot another vial of red liquid as the scene faded to white.

... ... ...

Jessica found herself in an empty void of pure white. She saw nothing but the man in the mask.

"Do you understand now, Jessica?"

"S-sort of... I mean, some of it. I guess he was basically forced into it. And that red stuff made him crazy. But he seemed like a pretty despicable person to begin with."

The man in the mask smiled warmly at her.

"Jessica, you can't take any of this knowledge back with you. But there is one more little piece I'm going to allow you to keep. Let's just call it... a dream. I'm going to leave you now, but when you wake up, everything will be different."

The man in the mask walked away, as the white void faded to black.

... ... ...

She found herself in Steve's attic. Boxes were neatly stacked, and furniture was carefully draped with sheets. A layer of dust coated everything. On top of one stack, she saw an open box containing several model aircraft - mostly fighter jets - as well as a baseball glove and a toy robot. Then she saw another open box full of framed pictures. One frame was lying on top, face down. She turned it over and saw the pilot in a cheap tuxedo with his arm around a pretty girl in a wedding dress. The glass was spotted with dried tears.

A flicker of motion caught her eye, and she saw Darwin trotting down the stairs. "Wait!" She rushed after the cat, down the stairs, and then saw her dart around the corner into the living room. "Charlotte Darwin, GET back here!"

When she followed, she saw Steve sitting on the couch. She froze, then started backing slowly into the hallway.

But he didn't see her. He was staring down at a small pistol in one hand, with a can of beer in the other. Darwin hopped onto the couch beside him and curled up, but he was completely unaware of her existence. He was mumbling to himself in a heavy slur.

"Why, Allie...? WHY? We had PLANS. We had a FUTURE! ...Why'd ya hafta get SICK?"

He doubled over in sobs that racked his body in lurches and shudders. Then he bolted upright and wiped his face with the back of his wrist, pistol in hand.

"Ssstupid doctors. I'll never pay 'em off... and they'll never bring you BACK!"

He stared down the barrel of the gun, into the salvation lurking in the darkness within. After a long while, his arm went limp and he leaned back in the couch.

The phone rang.

He ignored it for two rings, then gulped down the rest of his beer and answered it.

... ... ...

Jessica awoke in the Bio Lab, with tears streaming down over a trembling smile.

[8356287]

Adding to what Shadowlake said, here's the main thing to keep in mind: this is more of a story than a game. We're not really "players", we're authors writing a story together from our own character's perspectives. We only use dice to make our authorship more unpredictable and fun. But we don't have enough rules to keep the balance that a game needs to have. Also, the things that make a game challenging don't necessarily make a story interesting - like steel plates.

Try to think like an author. Think about your favorite book and movies - what do you like about them? What makes them interesting? Try doing those types of things.

A desire to kill PCs is not going to be fulfilled in this thread. The only PCs who have died, did so because their players wanted them to die - because it was interesting to the story.

I take that back - Misterme7's original character got shot in the head by another player's character, and it really sucked. It sucked for Misterme7, and it sucked for the story.

New rule: a PC will only die when their player wants them to die.

[8356287]
shadowlakeSounds interesting, i will give it a try. How does it work?:mush_planet_scanned_1:

Normally a scan wouldn't reveal all the information about a planet - the further away, the less info you can get. But since you're already in orbit, you'll get 100% of scannable info. (There are still a few stats that a scanner won't reveal, such as the Hostility of life-forms.)

Here is the planet generator:

Arheadge at (52 61 65)

Size: 1+1 zones

Temperature: 5
1 - Extremely cold
2 - Cold
3 - Cool
4 - Warm
5 - Hot
6 - Extremely hot

Atmospheric density: 5
1 - None
2 - Thin
3 - Light
4 - Moderate
5 - Heavy
6 - Extremely dense

Atmospheric composition: Rock
R - Inert
P - Breathable
S - Toxic
(if no atmosphere, this doesn't count.)

Storms: 13% (chance of storm per zone)
(if no atmosphere, a storm is a stellar plasma burst.)

Water surface area: 26%
(to calculate number of zones that are ocean/ice, rounded down)

Geologic composition: (percentage chance of finding each in a Geological discovery)
63% Sedementary rock
60% Igneous rock
11% Hydrocarbons
12% Metals
4% Crystalline formations (not crystalite!)
6% Exotic materials (give DrWinner a good excuse to make crazy weapons )

Seismic activity: 8% (chance of volcano/earthquake per zone)

Life Form complexity: 2
1 - None
2 - Vegetation
3 - Simple (insects and small predators)
4 - Complex (ruminants and large predators)
5 - Intelligent (but still only hunter-gatherer society)
6 - Civilized (simple technology, up to steam-power)
7 - Space-faring (comparable to present day or Daedalus-era technology)
8 - God-like (incredibly advanced technology, almost magical)

[8356287]

Yeah, I've been working on Random Planet Exploration!

First of all, I don't want to GM most of the time. The only purpose of this is to give us something fun to do when EoN/GK aren't available to GM.

I wrote a little script to easily calculate the distances to known locations. Its output looks like this:

Sol ( 40 15 57 ) - distance: 48 lightyears (Home of the Daedalus)
Forendor ( 27 63 19 ) - distance: 52 lightyears (Home of the Forendorians)
Jauvei ( 38 44 5 ) - distance: 63 lightyears (Women-ruled planet)
Earatoo ( 83 22 78 ) - distance: 51 lightyears (Ruins Planet)
Dakarr ( 83 72 61 ) - distance: 33 lightyears (Crossbow Republic)
Arheadge ( 52 61 65 ) - current location (Small, hot planet)
Pfaff ( 9 88 59 ) - distance: 51 lightyears
Mafrihad ( 35 68 73 ) - distance: 20 lightyears
Scratolosh ( 19 19 87 ) - distance: 57 lightyears
Tarsonus ( 30 68 74 ) - distance: 24 lightyears
Korhac ( 55 51 5 ) - distance: 60 lightyears
Adiun ( 14 11 28 ) - distance: 72 lightyears
Totaine ( 93 16 33 ) - distance: 68 lightyears
Sprevius ( 35 24 9 ) - distance: 69 lightyears
Gogve Nebula ( 1 73 82 ) - distance: 55 lightyears (Big Dust Nebula)
Forron Nebula ( 2 68 72 ) - distance: 50 lightyears (Planetary Nebula)
Lestion Nebula ( 11 86 13 ) - distance: 70 lightyears


The distance is used for Planet Scanning. Here's how it works: the distance is subtracted from the base percentage chance of detecting each of the following types of planet data:

Size: 150%
Temperature: 140%
Atmospheric composition: 130%
Atmospheric density: 120%
Storms: 110%
Fires: 100%
Seismic activity: 90%
Geologic composition: 80%
Life Form complexity: 70%

I redesigned some parts of the Planet Generator template so that there won't be any boring throw-away planets. The size of each planet is d4+4 zones, so that's 5 to 8 zones. And just to make it interesting, the catastrophic events now have a small chance of injuring or killing members of the expedition party. Of course, PCs are immune to death (at the player's choice), so that shouldn't be a reason to not visit a planet.

I completely redesigned the Zone Exploration templates so there's usually a good chance of encountering Intelligent Humanoids on most planets.

The types of zones are Forest, Mountains, Plains, Ocean. Each zone type has certain chance modifiers and unique events:

Forest

  • Storm -10%
  • Fire +5%
  • Life-form complexity +10
  • Fruit discovery

Mountains

  • Seismic Activity +5%
  • Fire -10%
  • Life-form complexity -10
  • Geological discovery

Plains

  • Storm +20%
  • Seismic Activity - none
  • Life-form complexity +20
  • Artifact discovery

Ocean

  • Fire - none
  • Storm +20%
  • Life-form complexity -20
  • Hydrocarbon discovery

A planet scan will reveal the zone type for a certain number of zones, calculated as:
size - distance/10
So a planet 20 lightyears away will reveal up to 6 zones for an 8-zone planet, but a planet 80 lightyears away won't reveal any.

The Expedition Team gets to choose which zones to explore, and in which order.


CATASTROPHIC EVENTS:

Storm

  • base percentage chance for planet: d20%
  • outcome roll:
    1-5 injuries/deaths
    6-70 no discovery
    71-100 discovery was still made

Fire

  • base percentage chance for planet: d12%
  • outcome roll:
    1-15 injuries/deaths
    16-50 no discovery
    51-100 discovery was still made

Seismic Activity

  • base percentage chance for planet: d8%
  • outcome roll:
    1-25 injuries/deaths
    26-100 discovery was still made

In the event of injury/death, each character gets a d6 roll:
1 - Safe
2 - Minor injury
3 - Moderate injury
4 - Severe injury
5 - Knocked out
6 - Killed


Planet temperature affects chances of catastrophes:

  • Extremely cold: Storm +20% ~ Fire -10%
  • Cold: Storm +10% ~ Fire -5%
  • Cool: Seismic Activity -3% ~ Storm +5%
  • Warm: Seismic Activity +3% ~ Storm -5%
  • Hot: Storm -10% ~ Fire +5%
  • Extremely hot: Storm -20% ~ Fire +10%

Each planet has a Life-form Complexity level (d8 roll):
1 - Uninhabited -30
2 - Simple -20
3 - Complex -10
4 - Medieval (0)
5 - Industrial +10
6 - Interplanetary +20
7 - Interstellar +30
8 - God-like +40


Each planet has a secret Hostility level, rolled as d20+d20+d20+d20+d20 (so it will tend to be very moderate, no extremes). A planet's Hostility is the base percentage chance of attack during Life-form Encounter.


The civilization of each planet has a secret Diplomacy level, also rolled as d20+d20+d20+d20+d20. This is the base percentage chance that the Intelligent Humanoids will accept a diplomatic action after a successful Diplomacy Skill roll. So Diplomacy has 2 ways of failing: a bad skill roll, or rejection by the aliens. A successful Diplomacy action can diffuse an attack into a peaceful encounter. It can also gain a new ally during a peaceful encounter. So attacking aliens can become allies after two successful Diplomacy actions.


Each zone explored gets a d100 roll for Life-form Encounter, modified by the Life-form Complexity of the planet and the zone:

1-40 No encounter

41-50 Small Herbivores

  • -40% Hostility
  • injury/death -3
  • d4 Alien Steaks

51-60 Small Predators

  • -20% Hostility
  • injury/death -2
  • d6 Alien Steaks

61-70 Large Herbivores

  • injury/death -1
  • d8 Alien Steaks

71-80 Large Predator

  • +20% Hostility
  • injury/death
  • d10 Alien Steaks

81-90 Behemoth

  • injury/death +1
  • d20+d20 Alien Steaks

91-100 Intelligent Humanoid

  • Hostility modifier determined by the planet's Life-form Complexity
  • Diplomacy also modified by Life-form Complexity

(In other words, more advanced aliens are more likely to attack, but also more likely to accept a Diplomacy action. You're also more likely to encounter advanced aliens than other life-forms.)

Humanoid alien attacks that aren't resolved through Diplomacy are fought as a battle through combat mechanics.


I also have mechanics defined for the discovery of Fruit, Artifacts, Hydrocarbons and Geological Specimens. But this post is already enormous, so I won't include them here.


One last thing: since we now know the distances between locations, we can keep track of the amount of time and fuel required to get there. Here's what I propose:

Pilgred Reactor

  • Speed determined by Pilgred Level (Currently 2.0 I think)
  • Powered by Crystals, obtained from Geological Specimens
  • Each Crystal provides d100+d100+d100+d100 lightyears worth of travel
  • We currently have 1 Crystal, with 76+13+57 lightyears remaining
  • Pilgred can be upgraded or broken

Rocket Thrusters

  • Speed is 0.5
  • Powered by Hydrocarbons
  • Each Hydrocarbon extraction provides d100 lightyears worth of travel
  • We currently have enough Hydrocarbons for 26+75+92 lightyears
  • Thrusters CANNOT be upgraded or broken

Travel time is distance x 10/speed minutes

The maximum possible distance in our coordinate space is (0, 0, 0) to (100, 100, 100) which is 173 lightyears. Maximum travel time with Rocket Thrusters would be 58 hours for that distance. But Pilgred could hop 60 lightyears in just 5 hours. Sound reasonable?


Suggestions are welcome. And don't panic about the complexity, I'll deal with all the tedious details and provide simple summaries with everything pre-calculated.

For expo injuries we would say everyone on the expo has a "endurance" of 50 or so. Let's say Bob and 3 NPCs go on an expo. They get to a place with a large predator group! If they failed to roll good to fight them off, and let's say the predators have a danger of 60. Being 4 Crew, divide the number of crew by 2 and round up. (equaling 2) That is how much you times the danger by. (120) Then, roll dice that can equal to that. (1d100 and 1d20) Let's say it was a 80. Being 4 crew, you divide that number by 4. (20) Everyone loses 20 endurance. A crew member has a coin flip to die when hurt when they are on 0. They are considered wounded and lose 10 to all rolls at 25 or lower. Does this sound good? If a PC gets messed with, the player can veto it. Your "no choice" nonsense isn't going to work. Every player is the GOD of their own characters. Remember that.

We're all equals here. Put that power-trip in check or I'm going to ignore everything you post.

Then that list is incorrect. We had 30 specific characters when the ship launched, some PCs and some NPCs. Each of them had specific skills, and each of them has had a specific history in the story.

Some of them are no longer on the ship:

Stark - former captain - infected with Forendor Virus, then killed
Samuel - "Pathfinder" - killed by Stark
Sauron - security officer - infected with Mush, then killed
Pilot (no name) - captured, infected with Mush, then shot, but the body escaped
Redshirt Engineer (no name) - captured, tested positive for Mush, left behind on Dakarr
Redshirt Pilot (no name) - killed in patrol ship

Another character, Blue Engineer, was also captured, but was brought back to the ship. Her name is now Natalie.

When we docked with the Crossbow space station, some additional people remained on the ship to become part of the crew. But we agreed at the beginning of Part 2, when the ship launched, that the Daedalus has maximum capacity for 30 people. It's hard enough keeping track of that many. I'd prefer less, but that was the agreement. 30 characters maximum.

That means you've got 6 NPCs to work with. Two of them can be your Redshirts. Please give ALL of them descriptions and skills, and post the current crew list to this thread. The crew list MUST be public information, because every player needs to know who is on the ship to be able to write things that make sense. If you want a stow-away to be hiding somewhere, that's fine, but you have to say so in the thread, and roll for their chance of being found if another character is in the same room. If a miscellaneous character shows up out of nowhere, I'm going to veto it.

[8356287]

There was some discussion about the weapons and armor of the ships a few pages ago. I wanted to mention some things about this before we get into combat.

Our pilots have been dropping like flies. We're down to 3 now - 4 if you count the Captain - but one of them is an inactive PC (Noodles/Manuel). There was a rule when the thread started that inactive PCs become NPCs until their player returns. We've never invoked that rule, but we might have to for this. Anyway, even with all 4 pilots and the Daedalus and the Ethereal battleship, that Aleliae Lord of the Storm looks like it could still smear us all in the dirt.

Our combat mechanics have never really worked very well. We usually don't even keep track of HP, because Thrump makes it irrelevant. It would be nice if we could spend a moment to come up with a reasonably well-balanced combat system. The rolls and modifiers are okay, but we might need to keep track of "turns" or something. Super powerful weapons shouldn't be able to fire every round.

I agree with GK that the Thrump is totally OP. IMHO, it needs a cool-down or something. Or just give it a specific damage against large objects like a ship, because an area-of-effect "delete" doesn't destroy the whole thing.

In short, if we're going to have a big battle, let's make it challenging but fair.

There was some discussion about the weapons and armor of the ships a few pages ago. I wanted to mention some things about this before we get into combat.

Our pilots have been dropping like flies. We're down to 3 now - 4 if you count the Captain - but one of them is an inactive PC (Noodles/Manuel). There was a rule when the thread started that inactive PCs become NPCs until their player returns. We've never invoked that rule, but we might have to for this. Anyway, even with all 4 pilots and the Daedalus and the Ethereal battleship, that Aleliae Lord of the Storm looks like it could still smear us all in the dirt.

Our combat mechanics have never really worked very well. We usually don't even keep track of HP, because Thrump makes it irrelevant. It would be nice if we could spend a moment to come up with a reasonably well-balanced combat system. The rolls and modifiers are okay, but we might need to keep track of "turns" or something. Super powerful weapons shouldn't be able to fire every round.

I agree with GK that the Thrump is totally OP. IMHO, it needs a cool-down or something. Or just give it a specific damage against large objects like a ship, because an area-of-effect "delete" doesn't destroy the whole thing.

In short, if we're going to have a big battle, let's make it challenging but fair.

So what is "Trump?"
Oh and I agree with Versatio.
